text: Hi everybody, this is Lino Coria and today I'm going to talk to you about arrays and lists.
You probably already know a lot about arrays and lists. You learn a lot in 5001, but I still want
to cover some of the basics. And in this video, I'm just going to talk about very generic things
about arrays and lists. And then in other videos, I'm going to talk about how arrays and lists
work in Java, specifically in Java. So why do we need arrays and lists? Well, we basically use them
to store collections of elements. So here I have some examples, for instance, your favorite songs.
Maybe you want to have somehow a collection of your favorite songs or the books that you have read this
year or the days of the week or the colors of the rainbow. Now, you can see that there's some
differences between some of these collections of elements here. For instance, your favorite songs,
they can change through your life. But for instance, the colors of the rainbow, they're not going to
change. They're always going to be the same or the days of the week. These collections are not going
to change. Right. And this is important and this is going to become more evident when we discuss about
what is an array, what is particular about an array, what is a list, what is specific about a list.
And then you're going to see why this different ways of storing information is useful.
Let's start by describing an array. What is an array? An array is a fixed size collection of elements
that are stored in order and in a continuous block of memory. And here is important to think this is
fixed size, right? So this is ideal for, say, the colors of the rainbow or the days of the week,
things that I know that are not going to change, that I know how many elements I need in my array.
And each element in an array is accessed using an index. And I'm going to give you an example so that
you can see what is it that I mean when I describe an array. Here I have an example with an array with
five numbers. The numbers are 10, 20, 30, 40, and 50. Now below these numbers, I have written the index
numbers that go from zero to four. Now you might be asking yourself, why do we go from zero to four?
And instead of say from one to five, that would make more sense. The way I look at this is the index
number is telling you how many elements you need to jump in order to get to the element that you're
looking for. So let's say I'm looking for number 10, which is the first element that shows up in the
array, then I need to jump zero times, zero numbers, right? But if I'm looking for number 40,
then I need to start at the beginning and then jump three numbers, right? So I go, I start at 10,
and then I go 20, 30, 40, three jumps, and then I get to number 40. And that's a way to look at the
index numbers in an array.
So arrays have these key features. They are fixed size. So if you say, I want an array of size seven,
well, you're not going to be able to change it, right? And that's okay. If seven is the colors of
the rainbow, well, they're not going to change or the days of the week, right? It's not going to
change. So keeping an array of seven, it's a good thing because we already know that this is the size
that we need, but we can access every element of the array very quickly. And also because everything
is on the same sort of chunk of memory, it's very efficient in terms of memory usage.
The one thing that we need to keep in mind is that all elements of the array must be of the same type.
So if you say this is a string, for instance, an array of strings, well, later you cannot say,
well, but I'm going to add a number here, right? Everything has to be a string.
Okay. So those were arrays. Now I'm going to talk about lists. What is a list? A list is a more
flexible way to store multiple values and it can shrink and grow as we need it. So this can be
useful when we need to be modifying things. And again, I'm not talking about specifics in Java,
how we handle lists. I'm going to cover that later here. I'm just talking generically. What is a
list? So here's an example of a list. Let's say I want to go grocery shopping and I write, I want
apples, I want bananas, I want carrots. And then I realized actually I don't like bananas that much,
right? So I scratch bananas and it's bad, but I do like oranges and I add oranges. So as soon as I
scratch bananas, then carrots go to the second spot here and then oranges goes to the third spot,
right? So I was able to modify my list, but then I might also think of blueberries. And so it's very
easy to add blueberries, right? And so a list is something that is made for changes. If I need to be
changing stuff and I need to be changing the size of my collection, then a list is the way to go.
So key features of a list. Well, they have flexible size, right? I can grow or shrink my list as needed.
And it's very easy to add or remove elements. And we're going to see that in Java, there are some
built in methods add, remove, contains other methods that make it really easy for us to work with list.
Anyway, I hope you understood the difference between an array in a list and we'll go into more detail in
the next videos. Thank you so much.
